meta.name: Create Jira Tickets from Streamlit Forms with Webhook & REST API

name: Automate Jira Ticket Creation from Your Streamlit App

parameters.jsCode: return [{ json: { ok: false, message: "Empty request blocked" } }];

parameters.content:
## Required


- Streamlit creation ticket app
- Jira account

## 1) Trigger & intake (Streamlit → n8n)

Purpose: receive the ticket from the app and hand it to the workflow.

Nodes

Webhook streamlit – receives action=create_ticket and a ticket object (id, projectKey, type, summary, description, priority, story_points, due_date, labels…).

raw data from streamlit (Set) – optional pass-through to visualize the raw payload in executions.

Setup

Webhook → Response mode: lastNode (so the final node’s response goes back to Streamlit).

Use the Production URL in the app (avoid the Test URL in production).

Don’t run the Jira HTTP node manually; always trigger through the Webhook.

## 4) Create issue in Jira

Purpose: call Jira REST API and create the real ticket.

Nodes

Processed data (Set) – passes through the fields object so you can inspect it.

Jira HTTP request (HTTP Request)

Method: POST

URL: https://<your-domain>.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/issue

Auth: Jira Software Cloud API (email + API token)

Headers: Content-Type: application/json (Accept optional)

Body: Raw JSON = { "fields": … } from the previous node (not a stringified “[object Object]”).

Expected output

Jira returns JSON with the new issue key (e.g., TES-123).

## 3) Normalize & build Jira payload

Purpose: transform app fields into a valid Jira JSON.

Nodes

Process streamlit data (Code) – outputs a clean fields object:

project.key (uppercase from projectKey)

issuetype.name (Task/Story/Bug/Epic)

summary

description in Atlassian document format (doc → paragraph → text)

Optional: priority.name, duedate (YYYY-MM-DD), labels (array)

Optional: customfield_10016 for Story Points (or your instance’s ID)

Notes

Don’t set assignee.name in Jira Cloud; use assignee.accountId only if you have it.

## 2) De-dup guard & branching (count/IF)

Purpose: prevent empty/invalid calls and duplicates from creating issues.

Nodes

anti double (Code) – builds a short-lived memory in workflow static data.

If ticket.id already seen (or fingerprint of projectKey+type+summary+description), mark as duplicate.

If action isn’t create_ticket or required fields are missing, mark as invalid.

IF for doubles

True branch (duplicate/invalid) → blocked request (Code) returns { ok: true, duplicate: true | ignored: true } to the Webhook and stops.

False branch (clean request) → continue.

Validation

Submit the same form twice quickly → True path should fire once (no second Jira issue).

“Test connection” from the app should be ignored and not create anything.

## 5) Return result to the app

Purpose: send a friendly response back to Streamlit.

Nodes

jira response (Set) – optional pass-through of the Jira response for visibility.

Result (Code) – returns to the Webhook:
{ ok: true, jiraKey: <KEY>, url: https://<domain>.atlassian.net/browse/<KEY> }

User experience

Streamlit shows the created key and a link to open the ticket.

Make sure to include your Jira space link in the Javascript code
